cluster.cot:
To answer the query about key mechanisms of how lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) form biomolecular corona with various serum proteins and blood components, I'll organize the quotes into meaningful dimensions.

First, I'll plan the dimensions:

1. "Introduction and Background" - This section should provide basic information about what LNPs and biomolecular corona are, establishing context for the reader. This will be in synthesis format to provide a coherent explanation of fundamental concepts.

2. "Formation Mechanisms of Biomolecular Corona" - This section should explain the key mechanisms and processes by which LNPs interact with blood components to form the corona. Synthesis format is appropriate as we need to explain processes and interactions cohesively.

3. "Components and Structure of the Corona" - This section should describe what proteins and blood components actually make up the corona and how they're structured (e.g., hard vs. soft corona). Synthesis format will allow for a comprehensive explanation of the corona composition.

4. "Factors Influencing Corona Formation" - This section should cover what properties of LNPs and environmental conditions affect corona formation. Synthesis format is best to explain these relationships.

5. "Biological and Therapeutic Implications" - This section should explain how the corona affects the behavior and efficacy of LNPs in biological systems. Synthesis format will enable a coherent explanation of these complex effects.

Now I'll assign quotes to each dimension:

sections.title: Introduction and Background
sections.tldr: Lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) form biomolecular coronas when they interact with proteins and other biomolecules in biological environments like blood. This corona formation is a spontaneous process that significantly alters the properties and biological identity of LNPs, influencing their therapeutic efficacy and cellular interactions. (10 sources)
sections.text:
Lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) have emerged as promising vehicles for therapeutic nucleic acid delivery, yet our understanding of their interactions with biological systems remains limited, particularly regarding the formation of biomolecular coronas and their impact on therapeutic outcomes. <Paper corpusId="239135396" paperTitle="(Liu et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> When LNPs enter biological environments such as the bloodstream, they undergo a spontaneous process where biomolecules, predominantly proteins, adsorb onto their surface, forming what is known as a biomolecular or protein corona. <Paper corpusId="274333034" paperTitle="(Catenacci et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="246187683" paperTitle="(Tomak et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> This phenomenon occurs rapidly through non-covalent interactions between the nanoparticle surface and surrounding proteins. <Paper corpusId="274333034" paperTitle="(Catenacci et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>

The protein corona essentially encapsulates the nanoparticle, creating a new biological identity that differs from the original LNP. <Paper corpusId="90881207" paperTitle="(Amici et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="263607931" paperTitle="(Amici et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> The most tightly bound proteins form what is referred to as the "hard corona," which primarily determines the nanoparticle's biological identity and subsequent physiological responses. <Paper corpusId="90881207" paperTitle="(Amici et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper> This interaction between LNPs and serum proteins results in a unique identification pattern that has been associated with novel recognition by cell receptors. <Paper corpusId="261886868" paperTitle="(Debnath et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>

The formation of protein coronas can occur in various biological environments, including ex vivo fluids like serum-containing culture media and in vivo fluids such as blood and tissue fluids. <Paper corpusId="269803646" paperTitle="(Gao et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> Protein-rich environments like the bloodstream and cytoplasm contain numerous proteins that can potentially interact with the corona. <Paper corpusId="273531369" paperTitle="(Renzi et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> These corona proteins significantly affect the properties of nanoparticles and their behavior within biological systems. <Paper corpusId="266124357" paperTitle="(Epanchintseva et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>

The study of proteins adsorbed to nanoparticles during circulation, commonly referred to as the protein corona, has been a significant research focus in the drug delivery field for many years. <Paper corpusId="269644493" paperTitle="(Simonsen, 2024)" isShortName></Paper> Understanding the mechanisms of corona formation and its influence on nanoparticle behavior is crucial for developing effective LNP-based therapeutics with predictable biological interactions and improved targeting capabilities.

sections.title: Formation Mechanisms of Biomolecular Corona
sections.tldr: Lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) spontaneously form biomolecular coronas through non-covalent interactions with blood components upon systemic administration. This dynamic process begins with rapid adsorption of abundant proteins followed by enrichment with high-affinity proteins, and is influenced by multiple factors including LNP composition, surface properties, and PEG shedding. (18 sources)
sections.text:
The formation of a biomolecular corona on LNPs occurs rapidly and spontaneously when these nanoparticles encounter biological fluids such as blood following systemic administration <Paper corpusId="274333034" paperTitle="(Catenacci et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="246187683" paperTitle="(Tomak et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. This process is driven by non-covalent interactions between biomolecules and the LNP surface, creating a coating that significantly alters the nanoparticle's biological identity <Paper corpusId="274333034" paperTitle="(Catenacci et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="268239296" paperTitle="(Francia et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. Initially, the corona contains considerable amounts of low-affinity but abundant proteins present in the biological medium, which over time are enriched with high-affinity proteins, reflecting the dynamic nature of corona formation <Paper corpusId="55245252" paperTitle="(Ianni et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="9545400" paperTitle="(Foroozandeh et al., 2015)" isShortName></Paper>.

A critical step in corona formation involves the shedding of polyethylene glycol (PEG) from the LNP surface, which exposes the underlying lipid structure to serum proteins <Paper corpusId="268238116" paperTitle="(Berger et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. This PEG shedding is influenced by the carbon chain length of the lipid conjugated to PEG, serum protein concentration, and exposure time <Paper corpusId="258076580" paperTitle="(Gyanani et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>. Studies have shown that pre-incubation of PEGylated LNPs in fetal bovine serum increases their cellular uptake proportionally to the amount of serum present and incubation time, suggesting that serum proteins stimulate PEG lipid release, though the precise mechanism remains unclear <Paper corpusId="258076580" paperTitle="(Gyanani et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>.

The physicochemical properties of LNPs, including their composition, charge, size, and surface chemistry, significantly influence the formation and composition of the protein corona <Paper corpusId="269341432" paperTitle="(Zhang et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="245405261" paperTitle="(Dilliard et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. Specifically, the ionizable lipid composition plays a major role in determining the proteins that adsorb to the LNP surface <Paper corpusId="220281961" paperTitle="(Witzigmann et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="218652381" paperTitle="(Miao et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. This relationship between LNP composition and corona formation has significant implications for targeting capabilities, as exemplified by the success of Onpattro®, which relies on ApoE in the corona for efficient targeting and gene regulation in hepatocytes <Paper corpusId="220281961" paperTitle="(Witzigmann et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>.

The corona structure consists of both "hard" and "soft" components. The hard corona comprises proteins that bind tightly and almost irreversibly to the LNP surface with high affinity, while the soft corona forms a looser, more dynamic layer that constantly exchanges with proteins in the environment <Paper corpusId="257252444" paperTitle="(Gonzalez-Rioja et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="261730930" paperTitle="(Monopoli et al., 2012)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="7596905" paperTitle="(Walczyk et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper>. Both components are considered relevant in determining LNP interactions with cells <Paper corpusId="257252444" paperTitle="(Gonzalez-Rioja et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>.

Protein corona formation can also influence the pH sensitivity of LNPs, as demonstrated by studies showing that preincubation of LNPs in serum shifted the onset of LNP binding and subsequent disintegration to lower pH, an effect less pronounced for lipoprotein-depleted serum <Paper corpusId="254658641" paperTitle="(Aliakbarinodehi et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. Additionally, the protein corona reaches maximum thickness when protein adsorption and desorption rates achieve equilibrium <Paper corpusId="268147071" paperTitle="(Lin et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>.

Understanding the mechanisms of corona formation is crucial because the resulting biomolecular layer can interfere with nanoparticle-cell interactions, induce immune responses, and alter drug-release efficiency <Paper corpusId="254318207" paperTitle="(Sartori et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. Moreover, the corona determines the LNP's stability, biodistribution, and tissue tropism, influencing its ultimate biological fate <Paper corpusId="268239296" paperTitle="(Francia et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="207559505" paperTitle="(Albanese et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>.

snippets: When NPs enter the bloodstream, some biomolecules interact with the LNP surface, resulting in their encapsulation and leading to the formation of a corona. This corona is commonly known as protein corona (PC) due to the predominant presence of plasma proteins (Amici et al., 2023). The PC formation is a spontaneous process that occurs rapidly thanks to noncovalent interactions between proteins and the LNP surface (Tomak et al., 2021).

paper.title: Effect of Lipid Nanoparticle Physico-Chemical Properties and Composition on Their Interaction with the Immune System

snippets: Abstract The surfaces of pristine nanoparticles become rapidly coated by proteins in biological fluids, forming the so-called protein corona. The corona modifies key physicochemical characteristics of nanoparticle surfaces that modulate its biological and pharmacokinetic activity, biodistribution, and safety. In the two decades since the protein corona was identified, the importance of nanoparticles surface properties in regulating biological responses have been recognized. However, there is still a lack of clarity about the relationships between physiological conditions and corona composition over time, and how this controls biological activities/interactions. Here we review recent progress in characterizing the structure and composition of protein corona as a function of biological fluid and time. We summarize the influence of nanoparticle characteristics on protein corona composition and discuss the relevance of protein corona to the biological activity and fate of nanoparticles. The aim is to provide a critical summary of the key factors that affect protein corona formation (e.g. characteristics of nanoparticles and biological environment) and how the corona modulates biological activity, cellular uptake, biodistribution, and drug delivery. In addition to a discussion on the importance of the characterization of protein corona adsorbed on nanoparticle surfaces under conditions that mimic relevant physiological environment, we discuss the unresolved technical issues related to the characterization of nanoparticle-protein corona complexes during their journey in the body. Lastly, the paper offers a perspective on how the existing nanomaterial toxicity data obtained from in vitro studies should be reconsidered in the light of the presence of a protein corona, and how recent advances in fields, such as proteomics and machine learning can be integrated into the quantitative analysis of protein corona components.

paper.title: Nanoparticle-protein corona complex: understanding multiple interactions between environmental factors, corona formation, and biological activity

snippets: After LNP administration, LNPs interact with biological fluids (i.e., blood), components of which adsorb onto the LNP surface forming a layer of biomolecules termed the "biomolecular corona (BMC)" which affects LNP stability, biodistribution, and tissue tropism. The mechanisms by which the BMC influences tissue-and cell-specific targeting remains largely unknown, due to the technical challenges in isolating LNPs and their corona from complex biological media.

paper.title: A magnetic separation method for isolating and characterizing the biomolecular corona of lipid nanoparticles
paper.venue: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America

snippets: After exposure of nanocarriers to biological fluids, biomolecules are rapidly adsorbed onto their surface forming the protein corona. The corona composition determines the biological identity of the nanoparticle and influences its toxicity, biological fate, circulation time, cell uptake, and drug release kinetics (Foroozandeh et al., 2015)(Caracciolo et al., 2017). At first, the protein corona includes considerable amounts of low-affinity proteins which abound in the biological medium. Over time, the composition of the corona is enriched with high affinity proteins (Caracciolo et al., 2017).

paper.title: Interaction of Solid Lipid Nanoparticles and Specific Proteins of the Corona Studied by Surface Plasmon Resonance

snippets: Protein corona has became a prevalent subject in the field of nanomedicine owing to its diverse role in determining the efficiency, efficacy, and the ultimate biological fate of the nanomaterials used as a tool to treat and diagnose various diseases. For instance, protein corona formation on the surface of nanoparticles can modify its physicochemical properties and interfere with its intended functionalities in the biological microenvironments. As such, much emphasis should be placed in understanding these complex phenomena that occur at the bio-nano interface. The main aim of this review is to present different factors that are influencing protein-nanoparticle interaction such as physicochemical properties of nanoparticle (i.e., size and size distribution, shape, composition, surface chemistry, and coatings) and the effect of biological microenvironments. Apart from that, the effect of ignored factors at the bio-nano interface such as temperature, plasma concentration, plasma gradient effect, administration route, and cell observer were also addressed.

paper.title: Merging Worlds of Nanomaterials and Biological Environment: Factors Governing Protein Corona Formation on Nanoparticles and Its Biological Consequences

snippets: In the second maturation step, removal of ethanol by dialysis against physiological buffer (pH 7.4) deprotonates the ionizable lipid and stabilizes LNPs. Inherently, LNPs contain at least five additional kinds of dynamic elements that determine their potency in a bioresponsive fashion; i) a PEG-lipid that, based on short (commonly dimyristyl) lipid anchors, is sheddable upon interaction with serum proteins in blood circulation; ii) a cholesterol/phosphatidylcholine envelope that triggers the formation of an apolipoprotein E-rich surface protein corona, facilitating receptor-mediated endocytosis into liver hepatocytes via the low-density lipoprotein receptor; iii) a cationizable tertiary amine-containing lipid (Fig. 1A), which after cellular uptake into acidifying endosomes becomes positively charged and changes physical properties; iv) interaction of cationized and anionic lipids trigger membrane destabilization promoting crossing of the endosomal barrier (Fig. 1B); and v) merging nanoparticle lipids with the cellular lipid membrane lead to release of the nucleic acid payload into the cytosol to a significant extent in carrier-free, bioavailable form (Xu et al., 1996)(Degors et al., 2019)(Zheng et al., 2022). Consequently, the LNP composition strongly influences protein corona formation, endogenous receptor targeting, and functional activity (Kimura et al., 2023).

snippets: The shedding of PEG relies on (i) shorter carbon chain lengths of the lipid that is conjugated to the PEG, (ii) the concentration of serum proteins in vivo, and (iii) the time of exposure to serum proteins [52]. In an in vitro study, Gallud et al. [52] demonstrated an increase in the uptake of PEGylated LNPs in Huh 7 cells when LNPs were pre-incubated in fetal bovine serum (FBS). Moreover, the increase in LNP uptake was proportional to the amount of FBS present and the time of incubation. They also showed that LNPs anchored to streptavidin via Biotin-mediated binding were released as the medium was exposed to FBS, providing a clear insight into the FBS-mediated release of PEG lipids. However, the precise mechanism of stimulation by serum proteins to augment the PEG lipid release from the LNPs is still unknown.

paper.title: Key Design Features of Lipid Nanoparticles and Electrostatic Charge-Based Lipid Nanoparticle Targeting

snippets: On one hand, following systemic administration, LNPs interact with specific proteins and biomolecules in the bloodstream, forming a layer of adsorbed ''protein corona'' on their surface. (Dilliard et al., 2021) The composition of this protein corona varies based on the type and properties of LNPs, including factors, such as composition, charge, size, surface chemistry, etc., predominantly affecting cellular uptake and biodistribution. (Ibrahim et al., 2022)

paper.title: Optimized lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) for organ-selective nucleic acids delivery in vivo

snippets: Significance Liver accumulation represents a significant barrier in the development of therapeutically efficacious nanoparticle drug delivery systems. Using a series of lipid nanoparticles with distinct organ-targeting properties, we provide evidence for a plausible mechanism of action for nanoparticle delivery to non-liver tissues. Following intravenous injection, specific proteins in the blood are recruited to the nanoparticle’s surface based on its molecular composition and they endow it with a unique biological identity that governs its ultimate fate in the body. An innovative paradigm emerges from this mechanistic understanding of nanoparticle delivery—endogenous targeting—wherein the molecular composition of a nanoparticle is rationally engineered to interact with specific proteins in the blood to overcome liver accumulation and to target specific organs. Lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) are a clinically mature technology for the delivery of genetic medicines but have limited therapeutic applications due to liver accumulation. Recently, our laboratory developed selective organ targeting (SORT) nanoparticles that expand the therapeutic applications of genetic medicines by enabling delivery of messenger RNA (mRNA) and gene editing systems to non-liver tissues. SORT nanoparticles include a supplemental SORT molecule whose chemical structure determines the LNP’s tissue-specific activity. To understand how SORT nanoparticles surpass the delivery barrier of liver hepatocyte accumulation, we studied the mechanistic factors which define their organ-targeting properties. We discovered that the chemical nature of the added SORT molecule controlled biodistribution, global/apparent pKa, and serum protein interactions of SORT nanoparticles. Additionally, we provide evidence for an endogenous targeting mechanism whereby organ targeting occurs via 1) desorption of poly(ethylene glycol) lipids from the LNP surface, 2) binding of distinct proteins to the nanoparticle surface because of recognition of exposed SORT molecules, and 3) subsequent interactions between surface-bound proteins and cognate receptors highly expressed in specific tissues. These findings establish a crucial link between the molecular composition of SORT nanoparticles and their unique and precise organ-targeting properties and suggest that the recruitment of specific proteins to a nanoparticle’s surface can enable drug delivery beyond the liver.

paper.title: On the mechanism of tissue-specific mRNA delivery by selective organ targeting nanoparticles
paper.venue: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America

snippets: It is important to mention that upon intravenous administration LNPs adsorb serum proteins on their surface. Many, if not all, of the abovementioned physiochemical characteristics impart distinct properties to the LNPs which ultimately influence protein adsorption. This "biomolecular corona" covering nanoparticles significantly impacts systemic circulation and nano-bio interactions (Monopoli et al., 2012)(Francia et al., 2019)(Albanese et al., 2014). Efficient targeting and gene regulation in hepatocytes stems from the presence of ApoE in the corona of LNPs and enabled the success of Onpattro® [33,76]. A recent publication suggested that the ionizable lipid composition plays a major role in the corona formed [165].

paper.title: Lipid nanoparticle technology for therapeutic gene regulation in the liver

snippets: Lipid-like nanoparticles (LNPs) have potential as non-viral delivery systems for mRNA therapies. However, repeated administrations of LNPs may lead to accumulation of delivery materials and associated toxicity. To address this challenge, we have developed biodegradable lipids which improve LNPs clearance and reduce toxicity. We modify the backbone structure of Dlin-MC3-DMA by introducing alkyne and ester groups into the lipid tails. We evaluate the performance of these lipids when co-formulated with other amine containing lipid-like materials. We demonstrate that these formulations synergistically facilitate robust mRNA delivery with improved tolerability after single and repeated administrations. We further identify albumin-associated macropinocytosis and endocytosis as an ApoE-independent LNP cellular uptake pathway in the liver. Separately, the inclusion of alkyne lipids significantly increases membrane fusion to enhance mRNA release, leading to synergistic improvement of mRNA delivery. We believe that the rational design of LNPs with multiple amine-lipids increases the material space for mRNA delivery. Lipid-like nanoparticles have applications as non-viral delivery systems for mRNA. Here, the authors develop biodegradable lipids with improved clearance and reduced toxicity.

paper.title: Synergistic lipid compositions for albumin receptor mediated delivery of mRNA to the liver

snippets: Proteins, which are the most important of these biomolecules, will adsorb -to some extent-on the NP surface, especially as PEG is removed, coating the surface with a new layer that will define the biological identity of the NP, the so-called "biomolecular corona", or "protein corona" (Walczyk et al., 2010)(Monopoli et al., 2012) which can dramatically alter the surface properties of nanosized particles and determine their in vivo fate (76)

This surface coating can be formed by hundreds of b i o m o l e c u l e s , i n c l u d i n g a l b u m i n , a p o l i p o p r o t e i n s , immunoglobulins, coagulation factors, and many others (77). Some of these biomolecules might associate almost irreversibly with the iLNP surface, in either their native or denatured form, affecting, de facto, all subsequent interactions. It has been proposed that the corona is comprised of both these tightly bound proteins ("hard" corona), which presumably bind directly to the iLNP surface with high affinity, and also a looser, more dynamic layer ("soft" corona) which constantly exchanges with proteins in the environment (78). The hard and soft corona are both considered relevant in determining iLNP interactions with cells (73).

paper.title: The development of highly dense highly protected surfactant ionizable lipid RNA loaded nanoparticles

snippets: The search for understanding the interactions of nanosized materials with living organisms is leading to the rapid development of key applications, including improved drug delivery by targeting nanoparticles, and resolution of the potential threat of nanotechnological devices to organisms and the environment. Unless they are specifically designed to avoid it, nanoparticles in contact with biological fluids are rapidly covered by a selected group of biomolecules to form a corona that interacts with biological systems. Here we review the basic concept of the nanoparticle corona and its structure and composition, and highlight how the properties of the corona may be linked to its biological impacts. We conclude with a critical assessment of the key problems that need to be resolved in the near future.

paper.title: Biomolecular coronas provide the biological identity of nanosized materials.

snippets: What the biological cell, organ, or barrier actually "sees" when interacting with a nanoparticle dispersed in a biological medium likely matters more than the bare material properties of the particle itself. Typically the bare surface of the particle is covered by several biomolecules, including a select group of proteins drawn from the biological medium. Here, we apply several different methodologies, in a time-resolved manner, to follow the lifetime of such biomolecular "coronas" both in situ and isolated from the excess plasma. We find that such particle-biomolecule complexes can be physically isolated from the surrounding medium and studied in some detail, without altering their structure. For several nanomaterial types, we find that blood plasma-derived coronas are sufficiently long-lived that they, rather than the nanomaterial surface, are likely to be what the cell sees. From fundamental science to regulatory safety, current efforts to classify the biological impacts of nanomaterials (currently according to bare material type and bare surface properties) may be assisted by the methodology and understanding reported here.

paper.title: What the cell "sees" in bionanoscience.
paper.venue: Journal of the American Chemical Society

snippets: Although it is clear that serum proteins will be adsorbed onto the surface of LNPs following the desorption of PEG-lipids upon systemic injections, the protein corona of different ligand-modified LNPs is not well studied yet. A recent study has reported that the nanoparticle protein corona would achieve a maximum thickness in biological fluids when the protein adsorption and desorption rates reached an equilibrium (Stordy et al., 2022).

paper.title: Surface engineering of lipid nanoparticles: targeted nucleic acid delivery and beyond

snippets: In vivo, lipid vectors for drug delivery adsorb proteins, lipids and other plasmatic biomolecules on their surface in a non-specific manner once injected: depending on the nanoparticles' properties, such as their charge, hydrophilicity, dimensions and morphology, the several components present in plasma interact and build a coating. The resulting biomolecular corona might interfere with the nanoparticle-cell interaction, induce an immune response and alter the drug-release efficiency (Al-Ahmady et al., 2018).

paper.title: Tailoring Lipid-Based Drug Delivery Nanosystems by Synchrotron Small Angle X-ray Scattering

snippets: A nanoparticle's physical and chemical properties at the time of cell contact will determine the ensuing cellular response. Aggregation and the formation of a protein corona in the extracellular environment will alter nanoparticle size, shape, and surface properties, giving it a "biological identity" that is distinct from its initial "synthetic identity". The biological identity of a nanoparticle depends on the composition of the surrounding biological environment and determines subsequent cellular interactions. When studying nanoparticle-cell interactions, previous studies have ignored the dynamic composition of the extracellular environment as cells deplete and secrete biomolecules in a process known as "conditioning". Here, we show that cell conditioning induces gold nanoparticle aggregation and changes the protein corona composition in a manner that depends on nanoparticle diameter, surface chemistry, and cell phenotype. The evolution of the biological identity in conditioned media enhances the cell membrane affinity, uptake, and retention of nanoparticles. These results show that dynamic extracellular environments can alter nanoparticle-cell interactions by modulating the biological identity. The effect of the dynamic nature of biological environments on the biological identity of nanoparticles must be considered to fully understand nano-bio interactions and prevent data misinterpretation.

paper.title: Secreted biomolecules alter the biological identity and cellular interactions of nanoparticles.

sections.title: Components and Structure of the Corona
sections.tldr: The biomolecular corona that forms on LNPs consists of a complex mixture of proteins including apolipoproteins, albumin, immunoglobulins, and coagulation factors, arranged in distinct "hard" and "soft" layers. This protein coating determines the biological identity of LNPs, with specific proteins like ApoE playing crucial roles in hepatocyte targeting while others affect distribution to different cell types. (11 sources)
sections.text:
The biomolecular corona that forms on lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) comprises a diverse array of proteins and other biomolecules that adsorb to the nanoparticle surface upon contact with biological fluids such as blood <Paper corpusId="257252444" paperTitle="(Gonzalez-Rioja et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>. This protein coating fundamentally alters the surface properties of LNPs and determines their biological identity, significantly influencing their in vivo fate <Paper corpusId="257252444" paperTitle="(Gonzalez-Rioja et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="261730930" paperTitle="(Monopoli et al., 2012)" isShortName></Paper>. The corona can contain hundreds of different biomolecules, with major components including albumin, apolipoproteins, immunoglobulins, coagulation factors, and various other serum proteins <Paper corpusId="257252444" paperTitle="(Gonzalez-Rioja et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>.

Structurally, the biomolecular corona consists of two distinct regions: the "hard" corona and the "soft" corona <Paper corpusId="257252444" paperTitle="(Gonzalez-Rioja et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>. The hard corona comprises proteins that bind almost irreversibly to the LNP surface with high affinity, potentially in either their native or denatured form <Paper corpusId="257252444" paperTitle="(Gonzalez-Rioja et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="90881207" paperTitle="(Amici et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper>. This tightly bound layer primarily determines the nanoparticle's biological identity and subsequent physiological responses <Paper corpusId="90881207" paperTitle="(Amici et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper>. Surrounding the hard corona is a more dynamic "soft" corona, which constantly exchanges proteins with the surrounding environment <Paper corpusId="257252444" paperTitle="(Gonzalez-Rioja et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>. Both layers are considered relevant in determining how LNPs interact with cells <Paper corpusId="257252444" paperTitle="(Gonzalez-Rioja et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>.

The composition of the protein corona is not random but depends on the intrinsic properties of the nanoparticles and influences their biological activity <Paper corpusId="231820159" paperTitle="(Aldosari et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="261730930" paperTitle="(Monopoli et al., 2012)" isShortName></Paper>. LNPs are known to interact with various opsonins in the blood, including immunoglobulins (IgG and IgM), fibronectin, and complement proteins, which can facilitate recognition and uptake by phagocytic cells, potentially leading to their elimination from circulation <Paper corpusId="231820159" paperTitle="(Aldosari et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

Specific proteins within the corona play crucial roles in determining the biodistribution and cellular targeting of LNPs. Notably, apolipoprotein E (ApoE) has been identified as a critical component for the delivery of certain LNPs to hepatocytes <Paper corpusId="271723470" paperTitle="(Alhabib et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="47397011" paperTitle="(Akinc et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper>. ApoE binds to cholesterol on the nanoparticle surface and acts as a ligand for low-density lipoprotein (LDL) receptors expressed on hepatocytes, ensuring predominant accumulation in liver cells <Paper corpusId="273570097" paperTitle="(Vasileva et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="249464961" paperTitle="(Sanchez et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="254774422" paperTitle="(Paunovska et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. This mechanism has been confirmed by experimental data showing that LNPs incubated with ApoE preferentially target hepatocytes <Paper corpusId="273570097" paperTitle="(Vasileva et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

In contrast, other protein corona compositions can direct LNPs to different cell types. For example, LNPs with a protein corona primarily composed of albumin tend to distribute preferentially to Kupffer cells rather than hepatocytes <Paper corpusId="273570097" paperTitle="(Vasileva et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. These differential targeting effects demonstrate how the specific composition of the protein corona can influence tissue tropism and cellular uptake mechanisms.

The protein corona not only affects the tissue distribution of LNPs but can also be leveraged to enhance or direct the delivery of therapeutic cargo <Paper corpusId="231820159" paperTitle="(Aldosari et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="16024780" paperTitle="(Neagu et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>. Indeed, LNPs fundamentally depend on protein corona formation to mediate their targeting capabilities <Paper corpusId="279032300" paperTitle="(Straten et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>. Understanding and potentially controlling the composition of the biomolecular corona therefore represents a significant opportunity for improving the efficacy and specificity of LNP-based therapeutics.

This surface coating can be formed by hundreds of b i o m o l e c u l e s , i n c l u d i n g a l b u m i n , a p o l i p o p r o t e i n s , immunoglobulins, coagulation factors, and many others (77). Some of these biomolecules might associate almost irreversibly with the iLNP surface, in either their native or denatured form, affecting, de facto, all subsequent interactions. It has been proposed that the corona is comprised of both these tightly bound proteins ("hard" corona), which presumably bind directly to the iLNP surface with high affinity, and also a looser, more dynamic layer ("soft" corona) which constantly exchanges with proteins in the environment (78). The hard and soft corona are both considered relevant in determining iLNP interactions with cells (73).

snippets: The search for understanding the interactions of nanosized materials with living organisms is leading to the rapid development of key applications, including improved drug delivery by targeting nanoparticles, and resolution of the potential threat of nanotechnological devices to organisms and the environment. Unless they are specifically designed to avoid it, nanoparticles in contact with biological fluids are rapidly covered by a selected group of biomolecules to form a corona that interacts with biological systems. Here we review the basic concept of the nanoparticle corona and its structure and composition, and highlight how the properties of the corona may be linked to its biological impacts. We conclude with a critical assessment of the key problems that need to be resolved in the near future.

paper.title: Biomolecular coronas provide the biological identity of nanosized materials.

snippets: In physiological environments (e.g. the blood), nanoparticles (NPs) are surrounded by a layer of biomolecules referred to as a 'protein corona' (PC). The most tightly NP-bound proteins form the so-called hard corona (HC), the key bio-entity that determines the NP's biological identity and physiological response.

paper.title: In vivo protein corona patterns of lipid nanoparticles

snippets: The formation of a bimolecular corona complex may change the surface properties of LNPs, and these changes can be adopted to enhance and/or target delivery of the loaded content (Monopoli et al., 2012)(Neagu et al., 2016). It is well-documented that the type and quantity of the individual proteins employed in the formation of bimolecular corona will be determined by the intrinsic properties of nanoparticles as well as their biological activity (Monopoli et al., 2012). LNPs are known to interact with blood proteins (opsonins), such as immunoglobulins (IgG and IgM), fibronectin, and a number of complement proteins. These interactions will facilitate recognition and uptake of nanoparticles by the phagocytic cells and, consequently, promote their elimination (Moghimi et al., 2017).

paper.title: Lipid Nanoparticles as Delivery Systems for RNA-Based Vaccines

snippets: When nanoparticles enter the bloodstream, they quickly adsorb proteins, forming a "corona" that modifies their behavior. For instance, apolipoprotein E (ApoE) can be critical for the delivery of certain LNPs to hepatocytes, whereas other LNPs may depend on different serum proteins like LDL or VLDL (Akinc et al., 2019)(Akinc et al., 2010).

paper.title: Advanced drug delivery systems for enhancing the efficacy of RNA-based therapeutics

snippets: Lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) have proven to be highly efficient carriers of short-interfering RNAs (siRNAs) to hepatocytes in vivo; however, the precise mechanism by which this efficient delivery occurs has yet to be elucidated. We found that apolipoprotein E (apoE), which plays a major role in the clearance and hepatocellular uptake of physiological lipoproteins, also acts as an endogenous targeting ligand for ionizable LNPs (iLNPs), but not cationic LNPs (cLNPs). The role of apoE was investigated using both in vitro studies employing recombinant apoE and in vivo studies in wild-type and apoE-/- mice. Receptor dependence was explored in vitro and in vivo using low-density lipoprotein receptor (LDLR-/-)-deficient mice. As an alternative to endogenous apoE-based targeting, we developed a targeting approach using an exogenous ligand containing a multivalent N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc)-cluster, which binds with high affinity to the asialoglycoprotein receptor (ASGPR) expressed on hepatocytes. Both apoE-based endogenous and GalNAc-based exogenous targeting appear to be highly effective strategies for the delivery of iLNPs to liver.

paper.title: Targeted Delivery of RNAi Therapeutics With Endogenous and Exogenous Ligand-Based Mechanisms.

snippets: After intravenous administration and entry into the bloodstream, a protein corona forms on the surface of LNPs, and this topic is investigated in detail in (Dilliard et al., 2021). The protein corona is capable of influencing the biodistribution of nanoparticles among tissues in various organs owing to the adsorption of the proteins on the tissue surface, leading to internalization via specific receptors. The best-studied mechanism of targeting of LNPs involves their uptake by hepatocytes via binding to low-density lipoprotein (LDL) receptors on their surface (Paunovska et al., 2022). The ApoE protein present in blood plasma is a ligand of LDL receptors and binds to cholesterol on the nanoparticles' surface and ensures their predominant accumulation in liver cells (Paunovska et al., 2022)(Sanchez et al., 2022). This mechanism is confirmed by experimental data where LNPs incubated with ApoE have been found to be targeted to hepatocytes (Johnson et al., 2022); on the other hand, particles with a protein corona composed of albumin are distributed preferentially into Kupffer cells instead of hepatocytes (Johnson et al., 2022).

paper.title: Composition of lipid nanoparticles for targeted delivery: application to mRNA therapeutics

snippets: To predict whether preclinical lipid nanoparticle (LNP) delivery will translate in humans, it is necessary to understand whether the mechanism used by LNPs to enter cells is conserved across species. In mice, non-human primates, and humans, LNPs deliver RNA to hepatocytes by adsorbing apolipoprotein E (ApoE), which binds low-density lipoprotein receptor (LDLR). A growing number of LNPs can deliver RNA to nonhepatocytes, suggesting that ApoE- and LDLR-independent interactions could affect LNP tropism. To evaluate this hypothesis, we developed a universal DNA barcoding system that quantifies how chemically distinct LNPs deliver small interfering RNA in any mouse model, including genetic knockouts. We quantified how 98 different LNPs targeted 11 cell types in wildtype, LDLR-/-, very low-density lipoprotein receptor, and ApoE-/- mice, studying how these genes, which traffic endogenous lipids, affected LNP delivery. These data identified a novel, stereopure LNP that targets Kupffer cells, endothelial cells, and hepatocytes in an ApoE-independent manner. These results suggest that non-ApoE interactions can affect the tropism of LNP-RNA drugs.

paper.title: Universal Barcoding Predicts In Vivo ApoE-Independent Lipid Nanoparticle Delivery.

snippets: Lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) have delivered therapeutic RNA to hepatocytes in humans. Adsorption of apolipoprotein E (ApoE) onto these clinical LNP-mRNA drugs has been shown to facilitate hepatocyte entry via the low-density lipoprotein receptor (LDLR). Since ApoE-LDLR trafficking is conserved in mice, non-human primates, and humans, characterizing this mechanism eased clinical transition. Recently, LNPs have delivered mRNA to non-hepatocytes in mice and non-human primates, suggesting they can target new cell types via ApoE- and LDLR-independent pathways. To test this hypothesis, we quantified how 60 LNPs delivered mRNA with cell type resolution in wild-type mice and three knockout mouse strains related to lipid trafficking: ApoE-/-, LDLR-/-, and PCSK9-/-. These data suggest that the hydrophobic tail length of diketopiperazine-based lipids can be changed to drive ApoE- and LDLR-independent delivery in vivo. More broadly, the results support the hypothesis that endogenous LNP trafficking can be tuned by modifying lipid chemistry.

paper.title: The Extent to Which Lipid Nanoparticles Require Apolipoprotein E and Low-Density Lipoprotein Receptor for Delivery Changes with Ionizable Lipid Structure.

snippets:
Abstract
With the expansion of the nanomedicine field, the knowledge focusing on the behavior of nanoparticles in the biological milieu has rapidly escalated. Upon introduction to a complex biological system, nanomaterials dynamically interact with all the encountered biomolecules and form the protein "bio-corona." The decoration with these surface biomolecules endows nanoparticles with new properties. The present review will address updates of the protein bio-corona characteristics as influenced by nanoparticle’s physicochemical properties and by the particularities of the encountered biological milieu. Undeniably, bio-corona generation influences the efficacy of the nanodrug and guides the actions of innate and adaptive immunity. Exploiting the dynamic process of protein bio-corona development in combination with the new engineered horizons of drugs linked to nanoparticles could lead to innovative functional nanotherapies. Therefore, bio-medical nanotechnologies should focus on the interactions of nanoparticles with the immune system for both safety and efficacy reasons.

paper.title: Protein bio-corona: critical issue in immune nanotoxicology

snippets: The protein corona that develops on the surface of nanoparticles after administration has garnered substantial attention due to the significant effects it has on their performance. Lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) depend on protein corona formation to mediate their targeting.

paper.title: Serum heat inactivation diminishes ApoE-mediated uptake of D-Lin-MC3-DMA lipid nanoparticles

sections.title: Factors Influencing Corona Formation
sections.tldr: Multiple factors influence the formation of biomolecular coronas on LNPs, including their physicochemical properties (size, charge, composition, surface chemistry), PEG shedding dynamics, and the specific biological environment they encounter. These factors collectively determine the composition and structure of the corona, which ultimately governs the biological identity and fate of LNPs in vivo. (8 sources)
sections.text:
The formation of the biomolecular corona on LNPs is influenced by a complex interplay of factors related to both nanoparticle properties and biological environments. The physicochemical characteristics of LNPs, including their composition, charge, size, and surface chemistry, significantly impact which proteins adsorb to their surface and consequently determine their biological identity and in vivo fate <Paper corpusId="220281961" paperTitle="(Witzigmann et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="269341432" paperTitle="(Zhang et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. Notably, the ionizable lipid composition plays a major role in determining the protein corona composition, which directly affects the targeting capabilities of LNPs <Paper corpusId="220281961" paperTitle="(Witzigmann et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>.

PEG shedding represents a critical factor in corona formation. When LNPs enter biological environments, the PEG layer that initially stabilizes them begins to shed, exposing the underlying lipid structure to serum proteins. This shedding process depends on several variables: the carbon chain length of the lipid conjugated to PEG, the concentration of serum proteins present, and the duration of exposure to these proteins <Paper corpusId="258076580" paperTitle="(Gyanani et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>. Studies have demonstrated that pre-incubation of PEGylated LNPs in serum increases their cellular uptake proportionally to both serum concentration and incubation time, suggesting that serum proteins actively stimulate PEG lipid release through mechanisms that remain incompletely understood <Paper corpusId="258076580" paperTitle="(Gyanani et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>.

The specific composition of the biological environment significantly influences corona formation. When LNPs encounter blood, they interact with various opsonins including immunoglobulins (IgG and IgM), fibronectin, and complement proteins, which can promote recognition and clearance by phagocytic cells <Paper corpusId="231820159" paperTitle="(Aldosari et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="261730930" paperTitle="(Monopoli et al., 2012)" isShortName></Paper>. The resulting biomolecular corona may contain hundreds of different proteins and other biomolecules, whose specific composition is determined by the intrinsic properties of the nanoparticles <Paper corpusId="231820159" paperTitle="(Aldosari et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

The dynamic nature of the biological environment also plays a significant role in corona formation. Upon intravenous administration, LNPs rapidly adsorb serum proteins on their surface, creating a coating that fundamentally alters their biological identity <Paper corpusId="220281961" paperTitle="(Witzigmann et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="257252444" paperTitle="(Gonzalez-Rioja et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>. This adsorption process is not random but is influenced by the properties of both the nanoparticle and the surrounding biomolecules <Paper corpusId="257252444" paperTitle="(Gonzalez-Rioja et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>.

The design of LNPs can be strategically engineered to influence corona formation. For example, cholesterol and phosphatidylcholine components in LNPs trigger the formation of an apolipoprotein E-rich surface protein corona, facilitating receptor-mediated endocytosis into liver hepatocytes via the low-density lipoprotein receptor <Paper corpusId="268238116" paperTitle="(Berger et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. This understanding has been exploited in the development of therapeutics like Onpattro®, whose success depends on the presence of ApoE in the corona for efficient targeting and gene regulation in hepatocytes <Paper corpusId="220281961" paperTitle="(Witzigmann et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>.

The resulting biomolecular corona can significantly impact therapeutic outcomes by potentially interfering with nanoparticle-cell interactions, inducing immune responses, and altering drug-release efficiency <Paper corpusId="254318207" paperTitle="(Sartori et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. Understanding these influencing factors is therefore crucial for designing LNPs with predictable in vivo behavior and optimized therapeutic efficacy.

snippets: It is important to mention that upon intravenous administration LNPs adsorb serum proteins on their surface. Many, if not all, of the abovementioned physiochemical characteristics impart distinct properties to the LNPs which ultimately influence protein adsorption. This "biomolecular corona" covering nanoparticles significantly impacts systemic circulation and nano-bio interactions (Monopoli et al., 2012)(Francia et al., 2019)(Albanese et al., 2014). Efficient targeting and gene regulation in hepatocytes stems from the presence of ApoE in the corona of LNPs and enabled the success of Onpattro® [33,76]. A recent publication suggested that the ionizable lipid composition plays a major role in the corona formed [165].

(Dilliard et al., 2021) The composition of this protein corona varies based on the type and properties of LNPs, including factors, such as composition, charge, size, surface chemistry, etc., predominantly affecting cellular uptake and biodistribution. (Ibrahim et al., 2022)

snippets: The shedding of PEG relies on (i) shorter carbon chain lengths of the lipid that is conjugated to the PEG, (ii) the concentration of serum proteins in vivo, and (iii) the time of exposure to serum proteins [52]. In an in vitro study, Gallud et al. [52] demonstrated an increase in the uptake of PEGylated LNPs in Huh 7 cells when LNPs were pre-incubated in fetal bovine serum (FBS). Moreover, the increase in LNP uptake was proportional to the amount of FBS present and the time of incubation. They also showed that LNPs anchored to streptavidin via Biotin-mediated binding were released as the medium was exposed to FBS, providing a clear insight into the FBS-mediated release of PEG lipids. However, the precise mechanism of stimulation by serum proteins to augment the PEG lipid release from the LNPs is still unknown.

snippets: The formation of a bimolecular corona complex may change the surface properties of LNPs, and these changes can be adopted to enhance and/or target delivery of the loaded content (Monopoli et al., 2012)(Neagu et al., 2016). It is well-documented that the type and quantity of the individual proteins employed in the formation of bimolecular corona will be determined by the intrinsic properties of nanoparticles as well as their biological activity (Monopoli et al., 2012). LNPs are known to interact with blood proteins (opsonins), such as immunoglobulins (IgG and IgM), fibronectin, and a number of complement proteins. These interactions will facilitate recognition and uptake of nanoparticles by the phagocytic cells and, consequently, promote their elimination (Moghimi et al., 2017).

paper.title: Lipid Nanoparticles as Delivery Systems for RNA-Based Vaccines

snippets: The search for understanding the interactions of nanosized materials with living organisms is leading to the rapid development of key applications, including improved drug delivery by targeting nanoparticles, and resolution of the potential threat of nanotechnological devices to organisms and the environment. Unless they are specifically designed to avoid it, nanoparticles in contact with biological fluids are rapidly covered by a selected group of biomolecules to form a corona that interacts with biological systems. Here we review the basic concept of the nanoparticle corona and its structure and composition, and highlight how the properties of the corona may be linked to its biological impacts. We conclude with a critical assessment of the key problems that need to be resolved in the near future.

paper.title: Biomolecular coronas provide the biological identity of nanosized materials.

snippets: Proteins, which are the most important of these biomolecules, will adsorb -to some extent-on the NP surface, especially as PEG is removed, coating the surface with a new layer that will define the biological identity of the NP, the so-called "biomolecular corona", or "protein corona" (Walczyk et al., 2010)(Monopoli et al., 2012) which can dramatically alter the surface properties of nanosized particles and determine their in vivo fate (76)

This surface coating can be formed by hundreds of b i o m o l e c u l e s , i n c l u d i n g a l b u m i n , a p o l i p o p r o t e i n s , immunoglobulins, coagulation factors, and many others (77). Some of these biomolecules might associate almost irreversibly with the iLNP surface, in either their native or denatured form, affecting, de facto, all subsequent interactions. It has been proposed that the corona is comprised of both these tightly bound proteins ("hard" corona), which presumably bind directly to the iLNP surface with high affinity, and also a looser, more dynamic layer ("soft" corona) which constantly exchanges with proteins in the environment (78). The hard and soft corona are both considered relevant in determining iLNP interactions with cells (73).

paper.title: The development of highly dense highly protected surfactant ionizable lipid RNA loaded nanoparticles

snippets: In the second maturation step, removal of ethanol by dialysis against physiological buffer (pH 7.4) deprotonates the ionizable lipid and stabilizes LNPs. Inherently, LNPs contain at least five additional kinds of dynamic elements that determine their potency in a bioresponsive fashion; i) a PEG-lipid that, based on short (commonly dimyristyl) lipid anchors, is sheddable upon interaction with serum proteins in blood circulation; ii) a cholesterol/phosphatidylcholine envelope that triggers the formation of an apolipoprotein E-rich surface protein corona, facilitating receptor-mediated endocytosis into liver hepatocytes via the low-density lipoprotein receptor; iii) a cationizable tertiary amine-containing lipid (Fig. 1A), which after cellular uptake into acidifying endosomes becomes positively charged and changes physical properties; iv) interaction of cationized and anionic lipids trigger membrane destabilization promoting crossing of the endosomal barrier (Fig. 1B); and v) merging nanoparticle lipids with the cellular lipid membrane lead to release of the nucleic acid payload into the cytosol to a significant extent in carrier-free, bioavailable form (Xu et al., 1996)(Degors et al., 2019)(Zheng et al., 2022). Consequently, the LNP composition strongly influences protein corona formation, endogenous receptor targeting, and functional activity (Kimura et al., 2023).

snippets: In vivo, lipid vectors for drug delivery adsorb proteins, lipids and other plasmatic biomolecules on their surface in a non-specific manner once injected: depending on the nanoparticles' properties, such as their charge, hydrophilicity, dimensions and morphology, the several components present in plasma interact and build a coating. The resulting biomolecular corona might interfere with the nanoparticle-cell interaction, induce an immune response and alter the drug-release efficiency (Al-Ahmady et al., 2018).

paper.title: Tailoring Lipid-Based Drug Delivery Nanosystems by Synchrotron Small Angle X-ray Scattering

sections.title: Biological and Therapeutic Implications
sections.tldr: The biomolecular corona that forms on LNPs significantly influences their biological fate by altering therapeutic efficacy, biodistribution, cellular uptake mechanisms, and immune responses. Understanding and manipulating corona formation offers opportunities to develop targeted LNP therapeutics with enhanced delivery capabilities beyond the liver. (19 sources)
sections.text:
The formation of biomolecular coronas on LNPs has profound implications for their therapeutic applications and biological interactions. When LNPs enter the bloodstream, the resulting protein coating fundamentally alters their surface properties, creating a new biological identity that determines their in vivo fate and significantly influences their therapeutic efficacy <Paper corpusId="220281961" paperTitle="(Witzigmann et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="207559505" paperTitle="(Albanese et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>. This altered identity can dramatically impact biodistribution patterns, cellular uptake mechanisms, and ultimately the therapeutic outcome of LNP-based treatments <Paper corpusId="268239296" paperTitle="(Francia et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

The protein corona plays a decisive role in determining the tissue tropism of LNPs, with specific corona compositions directing nanoparticles to different target tissues. Most prominently, the adsorption of apolipoprotein E (ApoE) onto LNPs enables hepatocyte targeting via binding to low-density lipoprotein receptors (LDLR), explaining the predominant liver accumulation observed with many LNP formulations <Paper corpusId="271723470" paperTitle="(Alhabib et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="47397011" paperTitle="(Akinc et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper>. This mechanism has been successfully exploited in clinical applications such as Onpattro®, whose efficacy stems from the presence of ApoE in the corona <Paper corpusId="220281961" paperTitle="(Witzigmann et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. Conversely, LNPs with coronas primarily composed of albumin tend to distribute preferentially to Kupffer cells rather than hepatocytes, demonstrating how corona composition can redirect tissue targeting <Paper corpusId="273570097" paperTitle="(Vasileva et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

Recent advances have revealed that the biomolecular corona can be strategically engineered to enhance targeting beyond the liver. The concept of "endogenous targeting" has emerged, wherein the molecular composition of nanoparticles is rationally designed to interact with specific proteins in the blood, enabling delivery to non-liver tissues <Paper corpusId="269341432" paperTitle="(Zhang et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="245405261" paperTitle="(Dilliard et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. This approach utilizes selective organ targeting (SORT) molecules whose chemical structure determines the LNP's tissue-specific activity by recruiting distinct proteins to the nanoparticle surface <Paper corpusId="261091800" paperTitle="(2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="245405261" paperTitle="(Dilliard et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

Beyond targeting, the biomolecular corona can influence several other critical aspects of LNP functionality. For instance, protein corona formation can shift the pH sensitivity of LNPs, altering the onset of binding and subsequent disintegration to lower pH values, which affects their endosomal escape capabilities <Paper corpusId="254658641" paperTitle="(Aliakbarinodehi et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. Additionally, the corona may interfere with nanoparticle-cell interactions, potentially inducing immune responses and modifying drug-release efficiency <Paper corpusId="254318207" paperTitle="(Sartori et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>.

The immune system's interaction with the protein corona represents another important consideration. LNPs can interact with various opsonins in the blood, including immunoglobulins and complement proteins, which may facilitate recognition and uptake by phagocytic cells, potentially leading to their elimination from circulation <Paper corpusId="231820159" paperTitle="(Aldosari et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="261730930" paperTitle="(Monopoli et al., 2012)" isShortName></Paper>. Understanding these interactions is crucial for developing LNPs with improved circulation times and reduced immunogenicity.

The dynamic nature of corona formation also has therapeutic implications. Initially, the corona contains considerable amounts of low-affinity but abundant proteins, which over time are enriched with high-affinity proteins <Paper corpusId="55245252" paperTitle="(Ianni et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="9545400" paperTitle="(Foroozandeh et al., 2015)" isShortName></Paper>. This evolution of corona composition can affect the timing and efficiency of therapeutic delivery.

Despite its importance, studying the biomolecular corona of LNPs presents significant technical challenges due to difficulties in isolating LNPs and their associated coronas from complex biological media <Paper corpusId="268239296" paperTitle="(Francia et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. Overcoming these challenges is essential for fully understanding and leveraging corona effects in therapeutic applications.

Recent research has revealed that cholesterol and phosphatidylcholine components in LNPs can trigger the formation of specific protein coronas that facilitate receptor-mediated endocytosis <Paper corpusId="268238116" paperTitle="(Berger et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. Additionally, studies have identified high-density lipoprotein (HDL) content in the corona as a potentially superior predictor of in vivo activity compared to the commonly used biomarker ApoE <Paper corpusId="275712592" paperTitle="(Zhang et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="259353478" paperTitle="(Liu et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>.

The growing recognition that LNPs fundamentally depend on protein corona formation to mediate their targeting capabilities <Paper corpusId="279032300" paperTitle="(Straten et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper> underscores the importance of intentionally designing LNPs to form specific coronas. This strategic approach represents a significant opportunity for improving the efficacy and specificity of LNP-based therapeutics, potentially enabling precise targeting of diverse tissues and cell types beyond the current limitations.

Many, if not all, of the abovementioned physiochemical characteristics impart distinct properties to the LNPs which ultimately influence protein adsorption. This "biomolecular corona" covering nanoparticles significantly impacts systemic circulation and nano-bio interactions (Monopoli et al., 2012)(Francia et al., 2019)(Albanese et al., 2014). Efficient targeting and gene regulation in hepatocytes stems from the presence of ApoE in the corona of LNPs and enabled the success of Onpattro® [33,76]. A recent publication suggested that the ionizable lipid composition plays a major role in the corona formed [165].

paper.title: Lipid nanoparticle technology for therapeutic gene regulation in the liver

snippets: A nanoparticle's physical and chemical properties at the time of cell contact will determine the ensuing cellular response. Aggregation and the formation of a protein corona in the extracellular environment will alter nanoparticle size, shape, and surface properties, giving it a "biological identity" that is distinct from its initial "synthetic identity". The biological identity of a nanoparticle depends on the composition of the surrounding biological environment and determines subsequent cellular interactions. When studying nanoparticle-cell interactions, previous studies have ignored the dynamic composition of the extracellular environment as cells deplete and secrete biomolecules in a process known as "conditioning". Here, we show that cell conditioning induces gold nanoparticle aggregation and changes the protein corona composition in a manner that depends on nanoparticle diameter, surface chemistry, and cell phenotype. The evolution of the biological identity in conditioned media enhances the cell membrane affinity, uptake, and retention of nanoparticles. These results show that dynamic extracellular environments can alter nanoparticle-cell interactions by modulating the biological identity. The effect of the dynamic nature of biological environments on the biological identity of nanoparticles must be considered to fully understand nano-bio interactions and prevent data misinterpretation.

paper.title: Secreted biomolecules alter the biological identity and cellular interactions of nanoparticles.

snippets: After LNP administration, LNPs interact with biological fluids (i.e., blood), components of which adsorb onto the LNP surface forming a layer of biomolecules termed the "biomolecular corona (BMC)" which affects LNP stability, biodistribution, and tissue tropism. The mechanisms by which the BMC influences tissue-and cell-specific targeting remains largely unknown, due to the technical challenges in isolating LNPs and their corona from complex biological media.

paper.venue: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America

snippets: When nanoparticles enter the bloodstream, they quickly adsorb proteins, forming a "corona" that modifies their behavior. For instance, apolipoprotein E (ApoE) can be critical for the delivery of certain LNPs to hepatocytes, whereas other LNPs may depend on different serum proteins like LDL or VLDL (Akinc et al., 2019)(Akinc et al., 2010).

paper.title: Advanced drug delivery systems for enhancing the efficacy of RNA-based therapeutics

snippets: Lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) have proven to be highly efficient carriers of short-interfering RNAs (siRNAs) to hepatocytes in vivo; however, the precise mechanism by which this efficient delivery occurs has yet to be elucidated. We found that apolipoprotein E (apoE), which plays a major role in the clearance and hepatocellular uptake of physiological lipoproteins, also acts as an endogenous targeting ligand for ionizable LNPs (iLNPs), but not cationic LNPs (cLNPs). The role of apoE was investigated using both in vitro studies employing recombinant apoE and in vivo studies in wild-type and apoE-/- mice. Receptor dependence was explored in vitro and in vivo using low-density lipoprotein receptor (LDLR-/-)-deficient mice. As an alternative to endogenous apoE-based targeting, we developed a targeting approach using an exogenous ligand containing a multivalent N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc)-cluster, which binds with high affinity to the asialoglycoprotein receptor (ASGPR) expressed on hepatocytes. Both apoE-based endogenous and GalNAc-based exogenous targeting appear to be highly effective strategies for the delivery of iLNPs to liver.

paper.title: Targeted Delivery of RNAi Therapeutics With Endogenous and Exogenous Ligand-Based Mechanisms.

snippets: After intravenous administration and entry into the bloodstream, a protein corona forms on the surface of LNPs, and this topic is investigated in detail in (Dilliard et al., 2021). The protein corona is capable of influencing the biodistribution of nanoparticles among tissues in various organs owing to the adsorption of the proteins on the tissue surface, leading to internalization via specific receptors. The best-studied mechanism of targeting of LNPs involves their uptake by hepatocytes via binding to low-density lipoprotein (LDL) receptors on their surface (Paunovska et al., 2022). The ApoE protein present in blood plasma is a ligand of LDL receptors and binds to cholesterol on the nanoparticles' surface and ensures their predominant accumulation in liver cells (Paunovska et al., 2022)(Sanchez et al., 2022). This mechanism is confirmed by experimental data where LNPs incubated with ApoE have been found to be targeted to hepatocytes (Johnson et al., 2022); on the other hand, particles with a protein corona composed of albumin are distributed preferentially into Kupffer cells instead of hepatocytes (Johnson et al., 2022).

paper.title: Optimized lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) for organ-selective nucleic acids delivery in vivo

snippets: Significance Liver accumulation represents a significant barrier in the development of therapeutically efficacious nanoparticle drug delivery systems. Using a series of lipid nanoparticles with distinct organ-targeting properties, we provide evidence for a plausible mechanism of action for nanoparticle delivery to non-liver tissues. Following intravenous injection, specific proteins in the blood are recruited to the nanoparticle’s surface based on its molecular composition and they endow it with a unique biological identity that governs its ultimate fate in the body. An innovative paradigm emerges from this mechanistic understanding of nanoparticle delivery—endogenous targeting—wherein the molecular composition of a nanoparticle is rationally engineered to interact with specific proteins in the blood to overcome liver accumulation and to target specific organs. Lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) are a clinically mature technology for the delivery of genetic medicines but have limited therapeutic applications due to liver accumulation. Recently, our laboratory developed selective organ targeting (SORT) nanoparticles that expand the therapeutic applications of genetic medicines by enabling delivery of messenger RNA (mRNA) and gene editing systems to non-liver tissues. SORT nanoparticles include a supplemental SORT molecule whose chemical structure determines the LNP’s tissue-specific activity. To understand how SORT nanoparticles surpass the delivery barrier of liver hepatocyte accumulation, we studied the mechanistic factors which define their organ-targeting properties. We discovered that the chemical nature of the added SORT molecule controlled biodistribution, global/apparent pKa, and serum protein interactions of SORT nanoparticles. Additionally, we provide evidence for an endogenous targeting mechanism whereby organ targeting occurs via 1) desorption of poly(ethylene glycol) lipids from the LNP surface, 2) binding of distinct proteins to the nanoparticle surface because of recognition of exposed SORT molecules, and 3) subsequent interactions between surface-bound proteins and cognate receptors highly expressed in specific tissues. These findings establish a crucial link between the molecular composition of SORT nanoparticles and their unique and precise organ-targeting properties and suggest that the recruitment of specific proteins to a nanoparticle’s surface can enable drug delivery beyond the liver.

paper.title: On the mechanism of tissue-specific mRNA delivery by selective organ targeting nanoparticles
paper.venue: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America

snippets: Upon intravenous injection, the nanoparticles come into contact with the serum, leading proteins to adsorb on their surface and form a distinctive protein corona layer (Dilliard et al., 2021). The presence of the protein corona may alter the properties of the nanoparticles, with profound influences for their tissue specificity. For instance, most LNPs exhibit hepatic specificity via intravenous administration, owing to the adsorption of ApoE by binding to the LDLR that are over-expressed on the hepatocytes (Dilliard et al., 2021).

snippets: After exposure of nanocarriers to biological fluids, biomolecules are rapidly adsorbed onto their surface forming the protein corona. The corona composition determines the biological identity of the nanoparticle and influences its toxicity, biological fate, circulation time, cell uptake, and drug release kinetics (Foroozandeh et al., 2015)(Caracciolo et al., 2017). At first, the protein corona includes considerable amounts of low-affinity proteins which abound in the biological medium. Over time, the composition of the corona is enriched with high affinity proteins (Caracciolo et al., 2017).

paper.title: Interaction of Solid Lipid Nanoparticles and Specific Proteins of the Corona Studied by Surface Plasmon Resonance

snippets: Protein corona has became a prevalent subject in the field of nanomedicine owing to its diverse role in determining the efficiency, efficacy, and the ultimate biological fate of the nanomaterials used as a tool to treat and diagnose various diseases. For instance, protein corona formation on the surface of nanoparticles can modify its physicochemical properties and interfere with its intended functionalities in the biological microenvironments. As such, much emphasis should be placed in understanding these complex phenomena that occur at the bio-nano interface. The main aim of this review is to present different factors that are influencing protein-nanoparticle interaction such as physicochemical properties of nanoparticle (i.e., size and size distribution, shape, composition, surface chemistry, and coatings) and the effect of biological microenvironments. Apart from that, the effect of ignored factors at the bio-nano interface such as temperature, plasma concentration, plasma gradient effect, administration route, and cell observer were also addressed.

paper.title: Merging Worlds of Nanomaterials and Biological Environment: Factors Governing Protein Corona Formation on Nanoparticles and Its Biological Consequences

snippets: In vivo, LNPs quickly adsorb plasma proteins to form a protein corona, showing a particular affinity for soluble apolipoprotein E (ApoE). This interaction promotes the binding of LNPs to low-density lipoprotein receptors (LDLr), which are highly expressed on the hepatocytes. Receptor-mediated endocytosis is a key mechanism for the internalization of LNPs by hepatocytes, partially explaining the preferential targeting of the liver by intravenously administered LNPs (Liu et al., 2023).

paper.title: Approaches and applications in transdermal and transpulmonary gene drug delivery

snippets: In terms of lipid nanoparticle (LNP) engineering, the relationship between particle composition, delivery efficacy, and the composition of the biocoronas that form around LNPs, is poorly understood. To explore this we analyze naturally efficacious biocorona compositions using an unbiased screening workflow. First, LNPs are complexed with plasma samples, from individual lean or obese male rats, and then functionally evaluated in vitro. Then, a fast, automated, and miniaturized method retrieves the LNPs with intact biocoronas, and multiomics analysis of the LNP-corona complexes reveals the particle corona content arising from each individual plasma sample. We find that the most efficacious LNP-corona complexes were enriched with high-density lipoprotein (HDL) and, compared to the commonly used corona-biomarker Apolipoprotein E, corona HDL content was a superior predictor of in-vivo activity. Using technically challenging and clinically relevant lipid nanoparticles, these methods reveal a previously unreported role for HDL as a source of ApoE and, form a framework for improving LNP therapeutic efficacy by controlling corona composition.

paper.title: Multiomics analysis of naturally efficacious lipid nanoparticle coronas reveals high-density lipoprotein is necessary for their function

snippets: The protein corona that develops on the surface of nanoparticles after administration has garnered substantial attention due to the significant effects it has on their performance. Lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) depend on protein corona formation to mediate their targeting.

paper.title: Serum heat inactivation diminishes ApoE-mediated uptake of D-Lin-MC3-DMA lipid nanoparticles
